awd_titl_txt: Hilton Head Solid State Sensors, Actuators and Microsystems Workshop, June 5-9, 2022
awd_abstract_narration:
ABSTRACT

This grant will fund travel for students and post-doctoral fellows who are US citizens to attend the Solid-State Sensors, Actuators and Microsystems Workshop, to be held over five days in Hilton Head Island, South Carolina from June 5 to June 9, 2022. This is the 20th in the series of Hilton Head Workshops on the science and technology of solid-state sensors, actuators, and microsystems. It is an exciting multidisciplinary event that has occurred biennially since 1984 with a rich history going back to the establishment of the field of Micro-Electro-Mechanical Systems (MEMS). The main theme of the workshop is Grand Challenges in Engineering and how microsystems technologies in combination with other technologies can address these challenges. Topics such as industrial short courses, MEMS and Sensors Industry Group (MSIG) special session, and early faculty development will also be addressed in special sessions within the workshop.

The travel awards enabled by this NSF grant provide travel assistance to US citizen students and post-doctoral associates of various groups including those underrepresented in science and engineering. The PIs will select travel award winners from the list of accepted papers paying close attention to diversity and inclusion including outreach to microsystems faculty in HBCUs, HSIs and 4-year Undergraduate in Engineering programs. The Workshop will benefit students with interest in academic and industrial careers as well as active faculty members. It is important to provide an inclusive climate for the participants and to help expand their network of professional contacts to ensure their future success. The hope is that they will return to their institutions inspired by their interactions and the technical content they witness at the workshop under the guidance of workshop leaders. The impact to the profession is recruitment and retention of well-informed personnel that feel supported and empowered. The website developed for the workshop will provide information about its activities and the organizing committee.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

inst.inst_name: The University of Central Florida Board of Trustees

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Introduction: Professor Swaminathan Rajaraman (PI) served as the Chair of the Commercial Development Committee while Professor Reza Ghodssi (Co-PI) served as the General Chair for the workshop. They oversaw all aspects of the travel grants.

 

Approach: The PIs diligently worked through the list of accepted papers and identified 32 candidates who were first and second authors of the accepted papers and were US citizens (students, junior faculty, and post-doctoral fellows) for the travel award. The PIs paid close attention to the diversity and inclusion in this awards selection process. The awards were typically $599. Some of the awardees received the entire registration amount ($925) due to additional work these students, faculty and post-docs performed for the meeting. Approximately 50% of the awardees (15) were either women or underrepresented minorities. All funds were distributed after the selection by the PIs through the UCF office of research. The PIs further organized an ?Early Experience Program? for underrepresented seniors and high school students and one of the awardees was from this exciting new category. Some of these awardees are showcased in Fig. 4.

 

Broader Impacts: The Hilton Head MEMS Workshop benefitted students with interest in academic and industrial careers as well as active faculty members. It is important to provide an inclusive climate for the participants and to help expand their network of professional contacts to ensure their future success. This community was empowered by the resources made available to them at this workshop. Our hope is that they returned to their institutions inspired by their interactions and the technical content they witness at the workshop under the guidance of workshop leaders. The impact to the profession is recruitment and retention of well-informed personnel that feel supported and empowered. Impact will also occur by targeting participants who are underrepresented in science and engineering in recruitment. The travel awards enabled by this generous NSF grant provided travel assistance to US citizen students of various groups including underrepresented ones.

 


Last Modified: 01/25/2023
Modified by: Swaminathan Rajaraman
